<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS

9702/23  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 300, 390, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[780, 300, 905, 316]]<|/det|>
May/June 2024  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[752, 325, 905, 341]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 395, 370]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 359, 400]]<|/det|>
No additional materials are needed.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 433]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 558]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 588, 213, 602]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 604, 729, 635]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 60.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 102, 688, 529]]<|/det|>
acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{- 2}\) speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00 \times 10^{8} \text{m s}^{- 1}\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60 \times 10^{- 19} \text{C}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1 \text{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{- 27} \text{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{- 31} \text{kg}\) Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02 \times 10^{23} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31 \text{J K}^{- 1} \text{mol}^{- 1}\) Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38 \times 10^{- 23} \text{J K}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67 \times 10^{- 11} \text{N m}^{2} \text{kg}^{- 2}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85 \times 10^{- 12} \text{F m}^{- 1}\) \(\left(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}}\right) = 8.99 \times 10^{9} \text{m F}^{- 1})\) Planck constant \(h = 6.63 \times 10^{- 34} \text{J s}\) Stefan- Boltzmann constant \(\sigma = 5.67 \times 10^{- 8} \text{W m}^{- 2} \text{K}^{- 4}\)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 564, 168, 580]]<|/det|>
## Formulae  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 596, 320, 613]]<|/det|>
uniformly accelerated motion  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 648, 250, 665]]<|/det|>
hydrostatic pressure  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 680, 151, 696]]<|/det|>
upthrust  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 721, 339, 739]]<|/det|>
Doppler effect for sound waves  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 759, 207, 775]]<|/det|>
electric current  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 790, 228, 807]]<|/det|>
resistors in series  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 826, 238, 843]]<|/det|>
resistors in parallel  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 100, 640, 121]]<|/det|>
\[g = 9.81 \text{m s}^{-2}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 131, 640, 150]]<|/det|>
\[c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 161, 625, 180]]<|/det|>
\[e = 1.60\times 10^{-19}\mathrm{C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 191, 630, 211]]<|/det|>
\[1 \mathrm{u} = 1.66 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 222, 630, 242]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67 \times 10^{-27} \mathrm{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 252, 630, 272]]<|/det|>
\[m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11 \times 10^{-31} \mathrm{kg}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 282, 648, 304]]<|/det|>
\[N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 314, 630, 335]]<|/det|>
\[R = 8.31\mathrm{~J~K}^{-1}\mathrm{~mol}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 345, 648, 365]]<|/det|>
\[k = 1.38\times 10^{-23}\mathrm{~J~K}^{-1}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 375, 688, 396]]<|/det|>
\[G = 6.67\times 10^{-11}\mathrm{N m}^2\mathrm{kg}^{-2}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 406, 650, 462]]<|/det|>
\[\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{-12}\mathrm{Fm}^{-1}\] \[(\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{-1})\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 472, 636, 492]]<|/det|>
\[h = 6.63\times 10^{-34}\mathrm{Js}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 503, 685, 523]]<|/det|>
\[\sigma = 5.67\times 10^{-8}\mathrm{Wm}^{-2}\mathrm{K}^{-4}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 595, 580, 635]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 647, 549, 666]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta p = \rho g\Delta h\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 676, 541, 695]]<|/det|>
\[F = \rho gV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 707, 555, 744]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{\mathrm{s}}V}{\nu\pm\nu_{\mathrm{s}}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 756, 551, 776]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 787, 608, 807]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 817, 613, 852]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}} +\ldots\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 705, 91]]<|/det|>
The drag force \(F_{\mathrm{D}}\) acting on a sphere falling through a liquid is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 102, 549, 122]]<|/det|>
\[F_{\mathrm{D}} = 6\pi \eta r\nu\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 406, 152]]<|/det|>
where \(r\) is the radius of the sphere,

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 149, 539, 167]]<|/det|>
\(v\) is the speed of the sphere in the liquid and

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[170, 164, 556, 183]]<|/det|>
\(\eta\) is a property of the liquid called the viscosity.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 196, 146, 214]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 195, 606, 214]]<|/det|>
Show that the SI base units of viscosity are \(\mathrm{kgm^{- 1}s^{- 1}}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 350, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 380, 146, 399]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 380, 920, 414]]<|/det|>
The sphere has a radius of \(3.0 \text{cm}\) and is falling vertically downwards at a terminal velocity of \(2.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) through the liquid. The drag force acting on the sphere is \(0.096 \text{N}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 450, 445]]<|/det|>
Calculate the viscosity of the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[494, 535, 920, 554]]<|/det|>
<form>viscosity = ......................................... $\text{kg} \text{m}^{-1} \text{s}^{-1}$

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 567, 146, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 567, 423, 585]]<|/det|>
The sphere is shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[126, 593, 870, 820]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 833, 532, 852]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 864, 920, 897]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.1, draw and label arrows to represent the directions of the **three** forces acting on the sphere as it falls at terminal velocity through the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[895, 880, 920, 898]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<label>2</label>

<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 912, 183]]<|/det|>
An object is projected horizontally at a speed of \(6.0 \text{m s}^{-1}\) from a slope, as shown in Fig. 2.1.

The slope is at an angle \(\theta\) to the horizontal. Air resistance is negligible.

The object lands on the slope a time of 0.71 s later and stops without rolling or bouncing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 425, 920, 444]]<|/det|>
<form>displacement = ................................................. m [2]

<label>(v)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[512, 675, 920, 693]]<|/det|>
<form>speed = ................................................. $\text{ms}^{-1}$ [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[833, 705, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 11]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 134, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 920, 198]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 777, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[477, 705, 920, 723]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 918, 166]]<|/det|>
State and explain qualitatively how the spring constant of the second sample compares with that of the original sample.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 883, 920, 902]]<|/det|>

<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 887, 91]]<|/det|>
The wave is a water wave produced by a dipper \(\mathsf{S}_1\) attached to a vibrator in a ripple tank.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 102, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
An identical dipper \(\mathsf{S}_2\) is attached to the same vibrator. The two dippers produce an interference pattern on the water in the tank, as shown in Fig. 4.3.

<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 318, 591, 336]]<|/det|>

The wave crests from each source are represented by solid lines on Fig. 4.3 and the wave troughs are represented by dashed lines.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 396, 875, 415]]<|/det|>
At point P in Fig. 4.3, the wave from \(\mathsf{S}_1\) has the same amplitude \(A\) as the wave from \(\mathsf{S}_2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 427, 712, 445]]<|/det|>

<mark>[3]

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 71, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
Use Kirchhoff's laws to show that the total resistance \(R_{\mathrm{T}}\) of the external circuit is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 97, 574, 131]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{1}{R_{\mathrm{T}}} = \frac{1}{R_{1}} +\frac{1}{R_{2}}.\]

<mark>[2]

<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 395, 920, 431]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[556, 647, 920, 666]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 648, 920, 666]]<|/det|>
